results.title: Sidney Poitier Was the Star We Desperately Needed Him to Be
results.abstract: Without the obstacles put in his way, he could’ve been even bigger than he was. But Mr. Poitier still managed to be a giant, which, in itself, is astonishing.

multimedia.caption: In civil rights-era Hollywood, Mr. Poitier was summoned to symbolize Black America, single-handedly; he was the first Black man to win the Academy Award for best actor.

results.title: Sidney Poitier, Who Paved the Way for Black Actors in Film, Dies at 94
results.abstract: The first Black performer to win the Academy Award for best actor, for “Lilies of the Field,” he once said he felt “as if I were representing 15, 18 million people with every move I made.”

multimedia.caption: Sidney Poitier’s Academy Award for the 1963 film “Lilies of the Field” made him the first Black performer to win in the best-actor category. He rose to prominence when the civil rights movement was beginning to make headway in the United States.
Sidney Poitier in 1959.

results.title: ‘A Hero’ Review: Debts No Honest Man Can Pay
results.abstract: In the latest film from the two-time Oscar winner Asghar Farhadi, a good Samaritan comes under suspicion.

multimedia.caption: Sahar Goldoust as Farkhondeh and Amir Jadidi as Rahim in “A Hero.”

results.title: Stream These Peter Bogdanovich Movies
results.abstract: The director loved the world of classic Hollywood so much that it’s as if he never left it. Here are nine of his film highlights.

multimedia.caption: Timothy Bottoms and Cybill Shepherd in “The Last Picture Show” (1971).

results.title: ‘Expedition Content’ Review: Anthropological Maneuvers in the Dark
results.abstract: An engrossing documentary looks back at a 1961 expedition to New Guinea and the creation of the landmark ethnographic film that resulted.

multimedia.caption: Listen up: A scene from the documentary “Expedition Content.”

results.title: What Is Happening With the 2022 Golden Globes?
results.abstract: A guide to everything we know  about the 79th annual Golden Globes on Sunday night.

multimedia.caption: Winners of the Globes will be announced on Sunday, but there will be no stars or red carpet.

results.title: Peter Bogdanovich, 82, Director Whose Career Was a Hollywood Drama, Dies
results.abstract: Within one decade, the ’70s, he was transformed from one of the most celebrated of filmmakers, notably for “The Last Picture Show,” into one of the most ostracized.

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich in 2007. He was hailed for his ability to coax nuanced performances from actors, and for the bittersweet luminosity of movies that conjured a bygone past.

results.title: ‘The 355’ Review: Exile in Bondville
results.abstract: Jessica Chastain, Penélope Cruz, Lupita Nyong’o, Diane Kruger and Fan Bingbing star in an espionage thriller that’s slick but banal.

multimedia.caption: From left, Penélope Cruz, Jessica Chastain, Diane Kruger and Lupita Nyong’o in “The 355.”

results.title: Golden Globes 2022: What to Expect Tonight
results.abstract: After controversies led to the cancellation of the broadcast, the show will go on — sort of. There won’t be any stars or cameras, but winners will be announced.

multimedia.caption: Statuettes were ready at the Beverly Hilton last week.

results.title: Quiet Awards Season Has Hollywood Uneasy
results.abstract: Audiences remain reluctant to return to theaters. And the kinds of movies that used to rely on the sheen of awards to attract moviegoers now find themselves in peril.

multimedia.copyright: Illustration by Delcan & Co.; Photograph by Peter Dazeley/Getty Images

results.title: Max Julien, Star of a Cult Blaxploitation Film, Dies at 88
results.abstract: Black audiences flocked to see him in “The Mack,” and generations of cinephiles have paid homage to his star turn, his smooth delivery and his extraordinary costumes.

multimedia.caption: The actor and screenwriter Max Julien in the title role of the 1973 film “The Mack.” The story of an ex-con who becomes a pimp, it was based on a story written in prison by an actual convict.

results.title: ‘It is a long journey to this moment,’ Poitier said in his 1964 Oscar speech.
results.abstract: Sidney Poitier made history in 1964 as the first Black performer to win an Oscar in the best-actor category for “Lilies of the Field.”

multimedia.caption: Sidney Poitier and Lilia Skala in “Lilies of the Field” (1963), for which he won an Oscar.

results.title: Stream These 11 Great Performances by Sidney Poitier
results.abstract: As an actor and filmmaker, he strove to bring layered Black individuals to the screen at a time when that was rare.
des_facet: In the Heat of the Night (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Sidney Poitier as a Philadelphia detective sent to help solve a case in a small Mississippi town in “In the Heat of the Night.”

results.title: ‘The Tender Bar’: A Tale of Drinking That Ducks Alcoholism
results.abstract: Though the memoir this film is based on confronts the issue of addiction to alcohol, the adaptation skirts the topic and its deeper implications.

multimedia.caption: Ben Affleck, left, and Tye Sheridan in “The Tender Bar.”

results.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include a family blood pact, a mother under attack, twins with a deadly secret, a father with demons and a couple that’s way too attached.
des_facet: My Heart Can't Beat Unless You Tell It To (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Owen Campbell in “My Heart Can’t Beat Unless You Tell It To.”

results.title: Harry Colomby, Teacher Who Aided a Jazz Great’s Career, Dies at 92
results.abstract: A chance encounter with Thelonious Monk led to a 14-year stint as his manager. After seeing a young Michael Keaton at a stand-up club, he became his manager, too.

multimedia.caption: Harry Colomby in 2015. He managed the pianist and composer Thelonious Monk for 14 years, from obscurity to renown; for most of that time, he was also a high school teacher.

results.title: ‘See for Me’ Review: Steal Away
results.abstract: A young blind woman is menaced by a crew of robbers in this forgettable thriller.

multimedia.caption: Skyler Davenport in “See for Me.”

results.title: The Oscars Want Crowd-Pleasers, but Where Are the Crowds?
results.abstract: As contenders like “West Side Story” and “Belfast” struggle for audiences, can a blockbuster like “Spider-Man: No Way Home” swing into the Oscar race?

multimedia.caption: A scene from “West Side Story,” one of several Oscar-worthy films that haven’t found their footing at the box office.

results.title: The Devils You Know: Three ‘Spider-Man’ Villains Return in ‘No Way Home’
results.abstract: Willem Dafoe, Alfred Molina and Jamie Foxx talk about reprising their bad-guy roles in the blockbuster sequel.

multimedia.caption: The “Spider-Man: No Way Home” menaces: from top, Jamie Foxx as Electro; Alfred Molina as Doctor Octopus; and Willem Dafoe as the Green Goblin.

results.title: They Screamed, We Screamed. Now They’re in ‘Scream’ Again.
results.abstract: After more than a decade, Neve Campbell, Courteney Cox and David Arquette return to take a new stab at the meta-horror franchise. They didn’t jump in right away.

multimedia.caption: From left: Neve Campbell, David Arquette and Courteney Cox are back for another go at “Scream.”
multimedia.copyright: Photographs by Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times

results.title: ‘American Gadfly’ Review: A Candid Candidacy
results.abstract: This documentary goes behind the scenes of Mike Gravel’s oddball run for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination.

multimedia.caption: From left, David Oks, Mike Gravel and Henry Williams in the documentary “American Gadfly.”

results.title: Hollywood Glamour Is Pandemic-Proof at the Polo Lounge
results.abstract: A clubby gathering spot attracts a who’s who of the film industry, and reminds them of a time when movies were still king.

multimedia.caption: The Polo Lounge is a popular gathering spot despite ongoing calls for a boycott because it is owned by the sultan of Brunei.
multimedia.copyright: Rozette Rago for The New York Times

results.title: A Film Captures Jewish Life in a Polish Town Before the Nazis Arrived
results.abstract: A documentary based on a home movie shot by an American in 1938 provides a look at the vibrancy of a Jewish community in Europe just before the Holocaust.
des_facet: Three Minutes in Poland: Discovering a Lost World in a 1938 Family Film (Book)

multimedia.caption: Images from a home movie titled: “Our Trip to Holland, Belgium, Poland, Switzerland, France and England, 1938,” which showed a Jewish community in Poland a year before the Nazi invasion.

results.title: ‘Mrs. Doubtfire’ on Broadway Is Pausing to Avoid Closing
results.abstract: The musical’s producer, eager to avoid a permanent shutdown amid the virus surge, is attempting a self-imposed nine-week hiatus.

multimedia.caption: “Mrs. Doubtfire” (starring Rob McClure, center) plans to temporarily close to save money on salaries and other expenses as the coronavirus surge takes a toll on Broadway.

results.title: 12 Things Our Critics Are Looking Forward to in 2022
results.abstract: “Better Call Saul” returns, Cecily Strong stars in a one-woman show, and Faith Ringgold gets an overdue retrospective.

results.title: Clifton Collins Jr. Hopes ‘Jockey’ Makes a Familiar Face a Familiar Name, Too
results.abstract: You know the actor from countless TV shows, but after immersive preparation for a rare leading role, he appears headed for a breakthrough.

multimedia.caption: “I’ve had other leading roles, just not like this,” said Clifton Collins Jr., who’s been winning accolades for his turn as an aging rider.
multimedia.copyright: Carlos Jaramillo for The New York Times

results.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: Our newest picks include a good cop-bad cop revenge thriller starring Donnie Yen, a high-tech animated take on Hansel and Gretel, and more.

multimedia.caption: Donnie Yen in a scene from “Raging Fire,” directed by Benny Chan.

results.title: Deaths in 2021: Headline Names Against the Backdrop of Pandemic
results.abstract: Aaron, Sondheim, Dole and Didion. But the loss of Colin Powell from the virus spoke most directly to the moment the world is in.

results.abstract: These are the pictures that defined an unpredictable year across the worlds of art, music, dance and performance.

results.title: ‘Poupelle of Chimney Town’ Review: Seeking Refuse
results.abstract: In this anime feature, a lonely boy strikes up a friendship with a trash creature and searches for stars in a polluted sky.

multimedia.caption: Poupelle (voiced by Tony Hale), left, and Lubicchi (voiced by Antonio Raul Corbo) in “Poupelle of Chimney Town,” directed by Yusuke Hirota.

results.title: ‘The Lost Daughter’ Review: The Parent Trap
results.abstract: This dreamy thriller follows an academic with a mysterious past who heads to a beach vacation on the Greek islands.

multimedia.caption: Dakota Johnson, left, and Olivia Colman in “The Lost Daughter,” Maggie Gyllenhaal’s feature directorial debut.

results.title: ‘Jockey’ Review: Hit Hard and Still Riding
results.abstract: In this plaintive drama, Clifton Collins Jr. plays a veteran jockey who has had one too many falls and is fast aging out of his profession.

multimedia.caption: Molly Parker and Clifton Collins Jr. in “Jockey,” from the director Clint Bentley.

results.title: At Home This New Year’s Eve (Unexpectedly)? Here’s What to Watch.
results.abstract: In case the Omicron spike has scrapped your plans, these binge watches, live broadcasts and double features will bring the party to you.
